customer_addr:
One Franklin Park Road
Boston, MA 02121

citations.narrative:
In the prehensile tailed porcupine exhibit and in bear back holding, there are cracks in the concrete flooring that are
several feet long. In the bear enclosure, dark material or moisture is visible accumulating in the cracked concrete.
Damaged floor surfaces that prevent adequate cleaning and/or sanitization can present a hazard to the animals. Housing
facilities shall be maintained in good repair for the safety of the animals. Correct by 1 October, 2024.
The chain link giraffe chute to outdoor holding was in poor repair and not structurally sound in several sections, with
several loose, crumpled areas with sharp points, braces no longer attached to some fenceposts, and a "V" shaped
opening between two poles at the entrance to the side yard. There is a risk of injury or entrapment from this disrepair.
Correct by 13 September 2024.
The interior of the giraffe barn had large holes in the insulation exposing the metal walls of the barn, and it was
deteriorating, reducing its efficacy and potentially compromising animal welfare by making it difficult to maintain adequate
temperatures in inclement weather. One of the intakes on the air handler was almost completely blocked with debris,
reducing airflow into the barn. Adequate ventilation is necessary to ensure animal welfare. Correct by 15 November,
2024.
A hand sized hole and multiple smaller, finger sized gaps were present in the concrete below one of the lion viewing
windows, and there were several 2 by 5 cm gaps in the deteriorating rubber seal around the jeep windshield in which the
public sits to view the lion. The lion has direct access to these windows while on exhibit. This risks injuring the public and
does not adequately protect the lion from the public. The facility immediately began repairs at the time of inspection. To
remain corrected after 12 September, 2024.
Metal flashing used to repair the exterior side of the male zebra stall in the exercise yard had a hole with sharp edges,
and a protruding edge, both of which could produce an injury if contacted by the zebra. To be corrected by ensuring that
facilities are maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury. Correct by 13 September, 2024.

The seals of multiple refrigerators used to store daily diets were blackened and in some cases caked with black material.
Buildup of debris and mold on door seals risks contamination and deterioration of food, which can lead to adverse animal
welfare outcomes. The facility must ensure that food is stored properly to ensure it is protected against deterioration or
contamination.
Correct by 13 September, 2024.

The surfaces of the walls above the corrugated panels and open grates comprising the roof of the sloth and tamarin
exhibit, under the flyway to feeding stations for birds and bats on the roof of the tropical forest exhibit, was caked with
droppings and dirt. Buildup of feces and biological material may harbor bacteria and mold that can adversely affect animal
welfare and attract pests. The facility must ensure that adequate cleaning is performed to ensure animal welfare.
Correct by 15 October 2024.

In the upper part of the aviaries in the Riverbank and Swamp exhibits, there were several hanging pieces of wire mesh on
the interior of the enclosures. Two or three of these sections of wire mesh had sharp, cut wire ends protruding into the
aviaries, which house multiple species.
A chicken wire panel used as a part of the floor in the barn owl's primary enclosure is corroded and damaged, with several
sharp wire points extending up into the enclosure.
In an enclosure holding two scarlet macaws, there is a wooden perching structure. In one area of the structure, the
wooden material of the perches has been worn away and the sharp point of a screw is exposed and accessible to the
birds in the enclosure. This item was corrected at the time of inspection.
To be corrected by ensuring that primary enclosures housing birds contain no sharp points or edges by 13 September
2024.

In three enclosures housing macaws and hornbills, there is a metal grate secured beneath the skylight in each enclosure.
The paint on the metal is patchy and peeling in some areas and the metal is dark and rough in appearance. A large (~8ft
long) piece of wood mounted to the ceiling near the grate in the hyacinth macaw enclosure has been damaged by the
birds and has a rough, splintered appearance. Surfaces in contact with birds must be either readily cleaned/sanitized or
replaced when worn or soiled. Peeling paint and damaged surfaces may not be readily cleaned or sanitized and may
present a hazard to the health and well being of the birds.
To be corrected by ensuring primary enclosures housing birds are maintained in good repair and surfaces in contact with
birds can be readily cleaned or replaced when worn or soiled. Correct by 1 November, 2024.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
The barn owl enclosure is located on the second story of a barn. The area around the enclosure is used as a general
storage, and the floor space is largely occupied with large boxes, various pieces of stored equipment, and empty
enclosures. The accumulation of items makes accessing the enclosure for husbandry more challenging, and a layer of
dust is visible on the items in the space around the animal enclosure. Premises where housing facilities are located must
be kept clean and free of accumulations of junk in order to protect the birds from injury and disease, to facilitate necessary
husbandry practices, and to reduce breeding and living areas for pests.
To be corrected by 1 October, 2024.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
The wattled crane enclosure had an excessive accumulation of avian waste from pest birds (sparrows) on the window and
walls, and mesh used to eliminate perching sites was torn and dangling in places on the upper walls of the shelter. Avian
pests may carry infectious disease, and buildup of wastes may contaminate the shelter. The facility must ensure that
effective pest control is in place in this enclosure.
Correct by 16 September 2024.
This inspection and preliminary exit interview were conducted on site with facility representatives from September 3-5th,
2024. A final exit briefing was conducted on September 11, 2024.
Additional Inspectors:
SARA TOBIAS, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
In the prehensile tailed porcupine exhibit and in bear back holding, there are cracks in the concrete flooring that are 
several feet long. In the bear enclosure, dark material or moisture is visible accumulating in the cracked concrete. 
Damaged floor surfaces that prevent adequate cleaning and/or sanitization can present a hazard to the animals. Housing

The chain link giraffe chute to outdoor holding was in poor repair and not structurally sound in several sections, with 
several loose, crumpled areas with sharp points, braces no longer attached to some fenceposts, and a "V" shaped 
opening between two poles at the entrance to the side yard. There is a risk of injury or entrapment from this disrepair. 
Correct by 13 September 2024.  
 
The interior of the giraffe barn had large holes in the insulation exposing the metal walls of the barn, and it was 
deteriorating, reducing its efficacy and potentially compromising animal welfare by making it difficult to maintain adequate 
temperatures in inclement weather. One of the intakes on the air handler was almost completely blocked with debris, 
reducing airflow into the barn. Adequate ventilation is necessary to ensure animal welfare. Correct by 15 November,

A hand sized hole and multiple smaller, finger sized gaps were present in the concrete below one of the lion viewing

public sits to view the lion. The lion has direct access to these windows while on exhibit. This risks injuring the public and

Metal flashing used to repair the exterior side of the male zebra stall in the exercise yard had a hole with sharp edges, 
and a protruding edge, both of which could produce an injury if contacted by the zebra. To be corrected by ensuring that 
facilities are maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury. Correct by 13 September, 2024. 
3.125(c)

Facilities, general. 
The seals of multiple refrigerators used to store daily diets were blackened and in some cases caked with black material. 
Buildup of debris and mold on door seals risks contamination and deterioration of food, which can lead to adverse animal 
welfare outcomes. The facility must ensure that food is stored properly to ensure it is protected against deterioration or 
contamination.  
 
Correct by 13 September, 2024. 
3.131(a) 
   
Sanitation. 
The surfaces of the walls above the corrugated panels and open grates comprising the roof of the sloth and tamarin 
exhibit, under the flyway to feeding stations for birds and bats on the roof of the tropical forest exhibit, was caked with 
droppings and dirt. Buildup of feces and biological material may harbor bacteria and mold that can adversely affect animal 
welfare and attract pests. The facility must ensure that adequate cleaning is performed to ensure animal welfare. 
 
Correct by 15 October 2024. 
3.153(a)(1)(i) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
In the upper part of the aviaries in the Riverbank and Swamp exhibits, there were several hanging pieces of wire mesh on 
the interior of the enclosures. Two or three of these sections of wire mesh had sharp, cut wire ends protruding into the 
aviaries, which house multiple species. 
 
A chicken wire panel used as a part of the floor in the barn owl's primary enclosure is corroded and damaged, with several 
sharp wire points extending up into the enclosure.  
 
In an enclosure holding two scarlet macaws, there is a wooden perching structure. In one area of the structure, the 
wooden material of the perches has been worn away and the sharp point of a screw is exposed and accessible to the 
birds in the enclosure. This item was corrected at the time of inspection. 
 
To be corrected by ensuring that primary enclosures housing birds contain no sharp points or edges by 13 September 
2024. 
3.153(a)(1)(ix) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
In three enclosures housing macaws and hornbills, there is a metal grate secured beneath the skylight in each enclosure. 
The paint on the metal is patchy and peeling in some areas and the metal is dark and rough in appearance. A large (~8ft 
long) piece of wood mounted to the ceiling near the grate in the hyacinth macaw enclosure has been damaged by the 
birds and has a rough, splintered appearance. Surfaces in contact with birds must be either readily cleaned/sanitized or 
replaced when worn or soiled. Peeling paint and damaged surfaces may not be readily cleaned or sanitized and may

present a hazard to the health and well being of the birds. 
 
To be corrected by ensuring primary enclosures housing birds are maintained in good repair and surfaces in contact with 
birds can be readily cleaned or replaced when worn or soiled. Correct by 1 November, 2024. 
3.158(c) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
The barn owl enclosure is located on the second story of a barn. The area around the enclosure is used as a general 
storage, and the floor space is largely occupied with large boxes, various pieces of stored equipment, and empty 
enclosures. The accumulation of items makes accessing the enclosure for husbandry more challenging, and a layer of 
dust is visible on the items in the space around the animal enclosure. Premises where housing facilities are located must 
be kept clean and free of accumulations of junk in order to protect the birds from injury and disease, to facilitate necessary 
husbandry practices, and to reduce breeding and living areas for pests.  
 
To be corrected by 1 October, 2024. 
3.158(d) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
The wattled crane enclosure had an excessive accumulation of avian waste from pest birds (sparrows) on the window and 
walls, and mesh used to eliminate perching sites was torn and dangling in places on the upper walls of the shelter. Avian 
pests may carry infectious disease, and buildup of wastes may contaminate the shelter. The facility must ensure that 
effective pest control is in place in this enclosure. 
 
Correct by 16 September 2024. 
 
This inspection and preliminary exit interview were conducted on site with facility representatives from September 3-5th, 
2024. A final exit briefing was conducted on September 11, 2024.

SARA TOBIAS, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
